title: 113_s1827
content: The Act may be cited as the "American Fighter Aces Congressional Gold Medal Act". Congress finds that American Fighter Aces are fighter pilots who have destroyed 5 or more confirmed enemy aircraft in aerial combat during wars. Less than 1,500 out of over 60,000 US military fighter pilots have achieved this status since World War I. American Fighter Aces have emerged from various conflicts such as the Spanish Civil War, Sino-Japanese War, Russian Civil War, and Arab-Israeli War. American Fighter Aces, including those from the Eagle Squadron, fought for freedom and democracy against axis powers before Pearl Harbor. They possess unique skills like courage and judgment, representing diverse backgrounds from every State in the Union. Less than 1,500 US military fighter pilots have achieved Fighter Ace status by destroying 5 or more confirmed enemy aircraft in aerial combat since World War I. American Fighter Aces demonstrate courage, keen marksmanship, and split-second thinking in aerial combat. Their training, bravery, and sacrifice exemplify the traits of the US military, including service to country and protection of freedom. These Aces have had distinguished careers in various fields and have played leadership roles in multiple war efforts from WWI to Vietnam. Their heroism is extraordinary. American Fighter Aces, highly skilled military pilots, boosted American morale during wars and trained cadets in combat tactics. Many Aces became test pilots post-service due to their superior flying skills. The American Fighter Aces, a highly decorated military group, includes Admirals in the Navy, Generals in the Army, Marines, and Air Force, and recipients of the Medal of Honor. The American Fighter Aces, a distinguished military group, includes high-ranking officers from various branches and recipients of the Medal of Honor. Congressional Gold Medal. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be presented to the American Fighter Aces for their heroic military service. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal, which will then be given to the Smithsonian Institution. The gold medal for the American Fighter Aces will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display or loan, with preference for locations affiliated with the Smithsonian. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering production costs. Proceeds from duplicate sales go to the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific sections of the United States Code. AN ACT to award a Congressional Gold Medal to the American Fighter Aces for their heroic military service in aviation warfare.
